passages.text: Shifting currents toward defense; globalmavy TAM analysis suggests several re- rating catalysts ahead; raise PTs for naval- related names

We have raised our PTs across the key shipbuilders with meaningful navy exposure: Hanwha Ocean (PT up to W140K), HHI (PT up to W660K), Mipo (PT up to W270K), KSOE (PT up to W510K), implying c.25- 30% upside to current share prices. We see more clarity on naval opportunities in both the US and global ex- US for Korean players: 1) US (TAM estimated to be \(\) 418B\(: we believe the recent Korea - US summit shows Korean builders will have an important role in revamping US navy capabilities and we expect more details to be unveiled with regard to order visibility and scope of cooperation; US experience should also help build strong track record for Korean builders in future orders; 2) global ex - US (TAM estimated to be\) \ \(199B\) : Hanwha Ocean being shortlisted as finalist for the Canada submarine order shows the global presence for Korean builders in terms of technology, delivery time, and cost competitiveness and we expect more order development to be presented in the near term. Hanwha Ocean is our top pick in the short term with several near - term order - related catalysts; HHI is our top pick in the mid - to - long term for meaningful valuation catch - up to Hanwha Ocean upon aggressive execution.

US navy opportunity update: The US navy plans to build around 360 vessels across the next 30 years at an estimated cost of \(\) 1T\(. For Korean builders, which would not be able to tap into the aircraft carriers and submarines, that leaves\) \ \(418B\) TAM, and an annual TAM of \(\) 14B\(. While few details came out of the recent Korea - US summit (link), we believe it indicates a potentially important role for the Korean builders in the US navy capability revamp. We await details, including US regulatory changes and navy shipbuilding orders, which should become clearer in the coming weeks.

Global ex- US opportunities: Based on our analysis of 1) battleship inventory changes over the past 10 years (2014- 2025) and 2) old ships in inventory, we estimate the total global ex- US navy TAM for Korean builders could be up to \(\) 199B\(from 37 countries). We see the highest potential in the ASEAN and LATAM regions, where the Korean builders have a strong track record, and have the highest restocking demand. Assuming 10 years of order placement, and Korean M/S of 30\% - 50\%, we expect HHI and Hanwha Ocean to see\) \ \(3 - 5B\) average annual revenue opportunities.

Earnings implications: We expect Hanwha Ocean and HHI to collectively record W21T sales from the navy business (vs. 2025E total sales of W29T) - Hanwha Ocean W12T; HHI W9T. We expect US navy sales to amount to W6.4T (W3.2T for both), and W11T sales from global ex- US navy business, with Hanwha Ocean focusing more on submarines, and Hyundai Heavy focusing on surface vessels. On the OP side, we expect the two to collectively record W2.1T and c.10% OPM (vs. 2025E total OP of W3.5T) - Hanwha Ocean W1.3T; HHI W0.8T. We expect US navy OPM to be at 8% (assuming a production split between Korea and the US), while the global ex- US OPM

- Stock picks: Our short-term top pick remains Hanwha Ocean given it has the strongest potential near-term order pipeline, including Canada and Poland submarine orders, and Thailand frigate re-orders. In the mid-to-long term, our top pick is HHI, which should see valuation catch-up to Hanwha Ocean as the company shows more aggressive execution (in terms of capacity expansion and marketing) and heightened order visibility.

The US navy wants to build around 360 vessels over the next 30 years at an estimated cost of \(\) 1T\(. For Korean builders, which would not be able to tap into the aircraft carriers and submarines, that leaves\) \ \(418B\) TAM, and an annual TAM of \(\) 14B\(. Excluding China, Korea has\) 70\% +\(of the global commercial shipbuilding capacity. Along with Japan, it is one of the few countries capable of meeting US shipbuilding demand. We think Korean shipbuilders can handle\) 50 - 70\% \(of orders (ex - aircraft carriers and submarines), with HHI and Hanwha Ocean each capturing\) 25 - 35\% \(, translating to\) \ \(4 - 5B\) average annual revenue opportunity.

Based on our analysis of 1) battleship inventory changes over the past 10 years (2014- 2025) and 2) old ships in inventory, we estimate total global ex- US navy TAM for Korean builders could be up to \(\) 199B\(includes 37 countries that we believe are reachable for Korean companies; of note, Korea has a track record of navy export to 23 countries). The biggest opportunities lie within Asia and the Americas, which is\) \leq 80\%\$ of our TAM estimate. By fleets, we expect the largest opportunities to come from nonnuclear submarines, frigates, corvettes, logistics ships and destroyers. We see the highest potential in the ASEAN and LATAM regions, where the Koreans have a strong track record, and have the highest restocking demand. Assuming 10 years of order placement, and Korean M/S of \(30\% - 50\%\) , we expect HHI and Hanwha Ocean to see \(\) 3- 5B\(average annual revenue opportunity.

Based on company guidance on capacity, we expect Hanwha Ocean and HHI to collectively record W21T sales from the naval business (vs. 2025E total sales of W29T) - Hanwha Ocean W12T; HHI W9T. We expect US navy sales to amount to W6.4T (W3.2T for both), and W11T sales from the global ex-US navy business, with Hanwha Ocean focusing more on submarines, and Hyundai Heavy focusing on surface vessels. On the OP side, we expect the two to collectively record W2.1T and c.10% OPM (vs. 2025E total OP of W3.5T) - Hanwha Ocean W1.3T; HHI W0.8T. We expect US navy OPM to be at 8% (assuming a production split between Korea and the US), while the global ex-US OPM should be at 15% (fully built in Korea). We think global ex-US projects could see margin expansion with Korean shipyards' rising experience leading to operating leverage and heightened efficiency.

Korean shipbuilders' share prices have rallied \(100\%\) YTD on average, largely driven by strong earnings revisions and several industry positives (e.g. US MASGA, global defense opportunities). Korean companies have seen upward revisions of \(38\%\) YTD in \(12\mathrm{m}\) fwd EPS (KSOE \(+32\%\) , HHI \(+48\%\) , Mipo \(- 7\%\) , SHI \(+10\%\) , Hanwha Ocean \(+109\%\) ), which contributed \(38\%\) to the share price rally.

Compared to KOSPI, the shipbuilding sector has significantly outperformed the index, with Hanwha Ocean leading the way due to its active involvement across US naval projects (e.g. MRO, Philly Shipyard, etc.). HD Hyundai Group Shipbuilders (KSOE, HHI, Mipo) traded slowly during 1Q25, but started to gain momentum in April on the back of promising earnings alongside expectations of a potential shipbuilding deal with the US (MASGA project).

Since 2010, Korea battleship exports stand at 49 units, with patrol and corvettes dominating roughly half of total exports, followed by frigates \((12\%)\) , amphibious assault ships & replenishment tankers (both \(8\%\) ), and submarines \((6\%)\) . The remaining vessel types are evenly divided between landing ships \((4\%)\) , replenishment ships \((4\%)\) , training ships \((4\%)\) , and landing crafts \((2\%)\) .

Delivery time tends to be lower for vessel types with high export mix, as patrol/ amphibious assault ships/corvettes typically take under 1.5 years per delivery vs. vessel types with higher weight/volume (frigate, replenishment ships, landing crafts) taking between 4\~7 years per delivery.
Table 10: Korea shipbuilding: Export by vessel type

By region, ASEAN countries have been the largest importers of Korean battleships since 2010 with a \(49\%\) mix (24 units delivered out of 49 total). Within ASEAN, the Philippines accounts for the majority of battleship exports with 13 units, having steadily imported diverse vessel types from Korean builders (frigates/corvettes/patrol ships/etc.). LATAM countries have also been major importers, with Peru and Colombia accounting for \(16\% /8\%\) of total battleship exports during the same period.

Since 2010, Korea builders' global navy arms transfer M/S stands at 5% (vs. 2% between 2000-2009 and 1% before 2000). Korea's share has been steadily growing across ASEAN, Europe, and LATAM over the past few decades vs. share loss in Asia/Oceania. Compared to the 2000s, Korea builders' M/S has grown most rapidly in ASEAN (13%p) and South America (18%p), followed by Europe (4%p).

The highest \(\%\) of aged inventory is with non- nuclear submarines especially in ASEAN, LATAM, MENA regions and Canada. By country, Russia and Eurasia have the most aged vessels; India/ASEAN/LATAM regions also have a high percentage of aged vessels.

Based on our calculations, we expect a \(\S 92\mathrm{B}\) opportunity in Asia from 10 countries - Australia, New Zealand, Bangladesh, India, Indonesia, Malaysia, Myanmar, Philippines, Thailand, and Vietnam. We note that ASEAN countries and India have seen sizable battle ship retirements over the past 10 years, while there are also a sizable number of old vessels still sitting in their inventories, which should lead to meaningful restocking demand. The Korean companies have a strong track record in the ASEAN region, exporting several corvettes, frigates, amphibious ships, and submarines; more recently, HHI and Hanwha Ocean have won orders from Thailand and Philippines to export frigates and corvettes. The key order pipeline includes Thailand's re- order for frigates, Philippines submarine, and Indonesia aircraft carrier.

According to the Congressional Budget Office's analysis of the navy's 2025 shipbuilding plan, the plan is projected to cost an average of \(35.5B for new ship construction. The goal is to build a fleet of c.360 vessels across the next 30 years, hoping to achieve an inventory level of close to 390 vessels (+ 134 unmanned vessels).
Figure 71: Navy ship purchases under the US navy's 2025 plan

Korean builders' TAM estimated to be \(\) 418B\$Among the vessels that the US wants to build, Korean builders would not be able to tap into aircraft carriers and submarines. We think the Korean builders are eligible to build logistics ships, destroyers, frigates, amphibious ships, and landing ships, which is 242 ships out of 360 ships. The total TAM would be \(\) 418B\$ based on CBO estimates, and an annual opportunity of \(\) 14B\$. Excluding China, Korea has \(70\% +\) of the world's commercial shipbuilding capacity. Along with Japan, it is one of the few countries capable of meeting US shipbuilding demand. We think Korean shipbuilders can handle \(50 - 70\%\) of orders (ex- aircraft carriers and submarines), with HHI and Hanwha Ocean each capturing \(25 - 35\%\) , translating to \(\) 4- 5B\$ annual revenue opportunity.
